docs.title: Recommended VS Code Extensions & Dev Container
docs.text:
Testing Testing 123 This will change locally but not in the repo!

The most efficient and reproducible way to work with this project is to use VS Code Dev Containers. If you open this workspace in a Dev Container, all required tools and extensions will be installed automatically.

If you are not using Dev Containers, install these extensions:

  • Python (ms-python.python): Required for Python development and running scripts.
  • Docker (ms-azuretools.vscode-docker): Required if you use Docker workflow.
  • Makefile Tools (ms-vscode.makefile-tools): Strongly recommended for running Makefile targets easily.

Optional but helpful:

  • Markdown All in One (yzhang.markdown-all-in-one): For enhanced Markdown editing.
  • Markdown Preview Enhanced (shd101wyy.markdown-preview-enhanced): For advanced Markdown preview, including math.
  • YAML (redhat.vscode-yaml): For editing mkdocs.yml and other YAML files.
  • GitHub Pull Requests and Issues (github.vscode-pull-request-github): For GitHub integration.
  • Remote - Containers (ms-vscode-remote.remote-containers): If using VS Code Dev Containers.

docs.title: Getting Started with Dev Containers
docs.text:
To work with this project in a reproducible environment, follow these steps:

  1. Clone the repository:
git clone https://github.com/your-username/your-repo.git
cd your-repo

  1. Open the project in VS Code.

  2. Reopen in Dev Container:

  3. If prompted, click "Reopen in Container".
  4. Or, open the Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P), then select: Dev Containers: Reopen in Container

VS Code will automatically build the container, install all dependencies and recommended extensions, and set up your environment.

You can now use the integrated terminal to run Makefile commands or use Docker as described below.

docs.title: How to Debug Like a Pro
docs.text:
Debugging is a superpower! Here are some tips:

  • Use print statements (but don’t forget to remove them).
  • Rubber duck debugging: explain your code to a rubber duck.
  • Take breaks—sometimes the answer comes when you least expect it.
  • Use a real debugger (VS Code, PyCharm, etc.).

Happy debugging! 🦆

docs.title: Markdown Extensions Demo
docs.text: This document demonstrates the use of various markdown_extensions available in mkdocs with pymdown-extensions. Each section includes a short explanation of the extension and a working example.

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text: [toc]

docs.title: Admonition
docs.text:
Provides styled callouts for notes, warnings, tips, etc.

Note

This is a note admonition.

Warning

This is a warning admonition.

docs.title: Codehilite
docs.text:
Adds syntax highlighting to code blocks. guess_lang can be disabled to avoid misclassification.

def hello():
    print("Hello, world!")

docs.title: TOC Permalink
docs.text: Adds clickable permalinks to each heading in the Table of Contents.

docs.title: Subsection Example
docs.text: This subsection has a permalink.

docs.title: Arithmatex
docs.text:
Supports MathJax or KaTeX for LaTeX-style math rendering.

\(E = mc^2\)

Inline math: \(a^2 + b^2 = c^2\)

docs.title: b64
docs.text:
Allows embedding base64-encoded images directly in Markdown.

![Red dot](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAYAAAAfFcSJAAAADUlEQVQIW2P4z8DwHwAFgwJ/l9hU3gAAAABJRU5ErkJggg==)

docs.title: betterem
docs.text:
Improves handling of emphasis (e.g., avoids nested emphasis bugs).

Italic vs Bold vs BoldItalic

docs.title: caret
docs.text:
Adds support for superscript.

This is superscript text.

docs.title: critic
docs.text:
Enables Critic Markup for editorial suggestions and inline changes.

deleted text added text {~~ replaced text ~> new text ~~} highlighted comment

docs.title: details
docs.text:
Creates collapsible blocks.

Click to Expand

This is hidden in a collapsible block.

docs.title: emoji
docs.text:
Replaces emoji shortcodes with Unicode or image emojis.

:tada:

docs.title: escapeall
docs.text:
Escapes all Markdown-sensitive characters by default.

*This* is not italic because of escapeall.

docs.title: extra
docs.text:
A bundle of useful extensions like abbreviations and tables.

Abbreviation: HTML*[Hyper Text Markup Language]

docs.title: highlight
docs.text:
Allows highlighting using == markers.

==Highlighted text==

docs.title: inlinehilite
docs.text:
Adds highlighting inside inline code blocks.

Here is some ==inline code== that’s highlighted.

docs.title: keys
docs.text:
Formats keyboard keys.

Press Ctrl+Alt+Del to reboot.

docs.title: magiclink
docs.text:
Auto-converts URLs and emails into links.

Visit https://github.com/ for more info.

docs.title: mark
docs.text:
Highlights text using == markup.

==Marked text==

docs.title: pathconverter
docs.text:
Automatically converts relative paths to absolute ones when needed (e.g., for images).

An image:

docs.title: progressbar
docs.text:
Creates text-based progress bars.

[= ] 25%

docs.title: smartsymbols
docs.text:
Automatically replaces common textual representations with symbols.

© ™ ® → → <-> ...

docs.title: snippets
docs.text:
Allows reusing content from other files.

--8← "snippets/example.md"

docs.title: striphtml
docs.text:
Strips raw HTML tags from Markdown output.

This paragraph will be stripped if striphtml is enabled.

docs.title: superfences
docs.text:
Supports advanced fenced code blocks like mermaid, plantuml, etc.

graph TD;
    A-->B;
    A-->C;
    B-->D;
    C-->D;

docs.title: tabbed
docs.text:
Creates tabbed content sections.

=== "Tab One" Content for tab one.

=== "Tab Two" Content for tab two.

docs.title: tasklist
docs.text:
Adds GitHub-style task lists.

  • Task one
  • Task two

docs.title: tilde
docs.text:
Enables strikethrough text using ~~.

Strikethrough text

docs.title: Why Markdown is Awesome
docs.text:
• It’s easy to read and write.
  • You can use it almost anywhere (GitHub, blogs, docs).
  • Supports code, math, images, and more.
  • Works great with MkDocs and Material theme!

Pro tip: Try using emojis and tables for extra flair! 😎

docs.title: Top 5 Python Tricks
docs.text:
1. List comprehensions: [x*x for x in range(10)]
  2. Unpacking: a, b = b, a
  3. F-strings: f"Hello, {name}!"
  4. The enumerate() function for loops
  5. Using zip() to iterate over multiple lists

Try them out in your next project!
